summary: This is an internal FBI email chain from August 28, 2019, discussing a public appeal for victims of Jeffrey Epstein. It includes a draft tweet and discussion about potential media strategy following new indictments.

persons.name: Amy J. Thoreson
persons.context: FBI Public Affairs Specialist in New York who drafts a tweet appealing for Epstein victims and is involved in internal communications about media strategy.

persons.name: Martin R. Feely
persons.role: Special Agent in Charge, Criminal Division
persons.context: FBI Special Agent in Charge of the Criminal Division in the New York Office, who sends the email forwarding the draft tweet and discusses potential on-camera interviews.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the FBI's public appeal, identified as having potential additional victims who are being sought.

connections.description: Colleagues within the FBI New York Office, collaborating on public communications and media strategy regarding the Epstein case.
Feely, as Special Agent in Charge, is involved in the FBI's investigation and public outreach efforts related to Epstein and his potential victims.
Thoreson is drafting public communications on behalf of the FBI to seek additional victims of Epstein.

events.title: FBI Drafts Public Appeal for Epstein Victims
events.description: The FBI New York Office drafts and internally circulates a tweet renewing an appeal for any possible victims of Jeffrey Epstein to come forward.

events.title: Discussion of Post-Indictment Media Strategy
events.description: FBI officials discuss the possibility of conducting an on-camera interview following any new indictments in the Epstein case, contingent on whether a press conference is held.

keyFacts: On August 28, 2019, the FBI New York Office was actively seeking more victims of Jeffrey Epstein through a public appeal via a drafted tweet.
The FBI believed there were more victims of Epstein who had not yet contacted law enforcement.
FBI officials were planning media strategy, including potential on-camera interviews, in anticipation of new indictments in the case.
The document shows internal FBI coordination between the Public Affairs Specialist (Amy Thoreson) and the Special Agent in Charge (Martin Feely) regarding public communications.
